Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of allorecognition in a basal chordate
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability of an individual to discriminate between self and non/self is called allorecognition, and is found throughout the animal kingdom. This immunological recognition process is controlled by incredibly diverse molecules, and individual animals have nearly unique combinations of these, essentially making an individual signature. The best example of this is tissue transplantation: successful transplantation depends on a match of these signatures between donor and recipient, or the tissue will be rejected as being foreign. The molecules responsible are also thought to control other processes, for example the ability to determine the relatedness of another individual. What is not understood is how these molecules can be so varied: the observed diversity is 10 to 100-fold higher than what evolutionary mathematical models predict. Equally important is how this diversity is recognized and acted upon. This proposal focuses on understanding the evolutionary forces which underlie the ability to create, maintain and respond to this genetic diversity. Botryllus schlosseri, is a marine animal whose well studied allorecognition reaction occurs rapidly and can be easily studied. The investigators have recently identified the molecules which underlie this process. Given its convenient life-history traits, coupled with results from other investigators, the investigators can now begin to characterize the events involved with creating and maintaining this genetic diversity of this organism. This includes describing the diversity within and among natural populations, which will lead to a clearer understanding of the evolutionary processes responsible. B. schlosseri also has behavioral responses thought to be controlled by these molecules, which will also be directly tested.
The basic appeal of these studies and the straightforward methodology attract numerous undergraduate and high school students (many from under-represented groups), and is incorporated into independent research projects every spring and summer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to discriminate self from non-self is called allorecognition, and is found in species throughout the animal kingdom. Allorecognition is important for multiple reasons: it is the process by which transplanted tissues are rejected in humans, and it can also be used for an individual to determine how closely related another individual is to them. In turn, this discrimination of relatedness can then be used for a variety of functions, for example, preventing closely related individuals from breeding together. However, while we know that many species have allorecognition, we don't understand how these different systems work. In addition, one characteristic of allorecognition common to all species is diversity. In other words, each indivdidual has a very rare genetic signature. 

Over the last 10 years, we have been developing a new system for studying allorecognition, an animal called a tunicate, which is closely related to the vertebrates. The species we work on, called Botryllus schlosseri, has an allorecognition reaction that is much simpler than that of the vertebrates, allowing us to study it at high resolution. In addition, like in humans, this system controls both transplantation, as well as detection of relatedness. The aims of our studies were to understand the evolutionary mechanisms which allow rare genetic signatures to exist, and begin to characterize these social interactions in natural populations and in the lab.

We started by analyzing genetic diversity of the genes which control allorecogition. We characterized the mechanisms which create and maintain the extraordinary diversity at these genes, and found signatures of natural selection.  Our second goal was to understand the amount of interaction that goes on in natural populations, and what role allorecognition plays. We made the surprising finding that allorecognition interactions occur significantly more than anyone had ever expected, and that about 70% of the individuals had come into contact with another individual and undergone an allorecognition reaction. Our final goal was to dissect the molecular interactions that go on during an allorecognition reaction. We discovered that multiple genes play a role in the final outcome, and have begun to unravel the complexity of this reaction, many of which were recently discovered, and completely novel. We found that allorecognition can have affects on behavior, which we are following up on now.
